properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero. Conditions will improve gradually during the night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T11:59:16-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Further snowfall accumulation: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Churchill Falls and vicinity, and Churchill Valley. Time span: continuing through Monday. Remarks: Snow will become heavy at times this morning and combine with strong northwesterly winds resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve overnight tonight as winds begin to ease. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Overnight, extreme wind chill values were being reported in Tadoule Lake. These extreme wind chill values will moderate today before returning again tonight. Extreme cold warnings will likely be spread to other regions in northern Manitoba today. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T02:24:55-00:00

Area: Tadoule Lake

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible Tuesday night or Wednesday. Total snowfall: up to 15 cm. Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia. Time span: Overnight Tuesday night until Wednesday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will track south of Nova Scotia Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow is forecast to begin over southwestern Nova Scotia Tuesday afternoon and then spread eastward reaching Cape Breton on Wednesday. The track of the low is somewhat uncertain at this time. However, indications are that the Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia will likely receive the most accumulation. There is a fair degree of confidence that the Wednesday morning commute will be impacted by this snowfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T00:40:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T08:41:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3866479855.2019

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:

Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h tonight into Monday. Location: Churchill Valley. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow and strong northwesterly winds will result in poor visibility in blowing snow. The blowing snow will persist into Monday night. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: locally up to 10 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up 100 km/h along the south coast tonight and Tuesday morning Locations: Connaigre, the Burin Peninsula, and the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: this morning until this evening. Remarks: Flurries and local snow squalls will continue to develop this morning. Strong westerly winds accompanying these squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T01:22:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T09:23:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2834084215.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast Monday night. Winds will rise Monday evening as the warm front nears and then reach 90 km/h late Monday evening ahead of the low pressure centre. As the low passes overnight Monday, winds will ease and shift to westerlies of 50 km/h. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T22:37:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T06:38:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3213086119.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: generally 10 to 20 cm except locally 30 cm or more in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except locally as high as 110 km/h from the Port au Port Peninsula south to Port aux Basques Monday afternoon and Monday night. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Hawke's Bay, and Deer Lake - Humber Valley. Time span: overnight tonight until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Intense snow squalls are expected to develop early Monday morning in conjunction with very strong westerly winds. Visibility will be frequently reduced to near zero to give blizzard like conditions in blowing snow. Little improvement is expected until winds begin to ease on Tuesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-16T17:48:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T01:49:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3222903858.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2019-12-15. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast today. An intense low pressure system will produce strong to high winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high amplitude tides could produce breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-12-16, from 03:00 AM to 07:00 AM. 2019-12-16, from 03:00 PM to 07:00 PM. Matane: 2019-12-16, from 03:00 AM to 07:00 AM. 2019-12-16, from 03:00 PM to 07:00 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 AM to 06:30 AM. 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Minganie: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Anticosti: 2019-12-16, from 02:30 PM to 06:30 PM. Natashquan: 2019-12-16, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. Chevery: 2019-12-16, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T01:43:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T09:44:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0290898780.2019
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast Monday night. Ahead of the front, heavy snow will develop for inland areas of the north coast beginning as early as Monday afternoon. As the warm air moves onto the coast, snow will change to freezing rain at Kitimat and spread toward Terrace. Overnight Monday, Kitimat will likely change to rain while freezing rain persists inland. At Stewart, precipitation is expected to remain as snow Monday night and Tuesday morning with total snowfall amounts near 25 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-16T22:36:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T06:37:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3248678334.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected. Visibilities will be significantly reduced in areas of heavy snow and blowing snow with very strong winds. Total snowfall: locally 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: early this morning until this evening. Remarks: Very strong winds with flurries at times heavy and snow squalls are expected to develop early this morning and persist today. Conditions are expected to gradually improve tonight. A wind warning is also in effect for westerly winds gusting up 100 km/h over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T00:42:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T08:43:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0360512203.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts; 90 km/h. Location: Coastal areas of the Acadian Peninsula. Time span: Today. Remarks: Westerly winds gusting to 90 km/h are expected to continue today. The strongest gusts will be along exposed areas near the coast. Gusts will diminish to 70 km/h late this evening. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T00:39:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T08:40:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0758413688.2019
Area: Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 80 km/h, except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: southern Newfoundland. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Areas of dense fog have developed in the Similkameen region. The fog will persist until early Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: locally 10 to 20 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up to 100 km/h along the coast tonight and Tuesday morning. Locations: Burgeo and the Burgeo Highway. Time span: this morning until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Flurries and intense snow squalls will continue to develop this morning with strengthening westerly winds. Visibilities are expected to be near zero in snow squalls and blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to continue to produce blizzard conditions inland along the Burgeo highway tonight. Conditions will improve along the coast this evening. Highway conditions will improve Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T00:48:38-00:00
